protocol_name: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
protocol_name_html: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting

materials.reagent_name: EasySep Direct Human Monocyte Isolation Kit

status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Collect blood into K2EDTA vacutainer tube and invert several times.  Store at RT until use.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect blood into K2EDTA vacutainer tube and invert several times.  Store at RT until use.

components.data: Aliquot whole blood into 14 ml tubes.  Each tube receives 4 ml of blood.  A successful isolation will yield 1-2×10^6 total cells (>90% monocytes) per 4 ml of blood.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Aliquot whole blood into 14 ml tubes.  Each tube receives 4 ml of blood.  A successful isolation will yield 1-2×10^6 total cells (>90% monocytes) per 4 ml of blood.

components.data: Vortex RapidSpheres (brown reagent) from monocyte isolation kit well (15-30 sec).  Vortex isolation cocktail (clear reagent) from monocyte isolation kit (5 sec).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Vortex RapidSpheres (brown reagent) from monocyte isolation kit well (15-30 sec).  Vortex isolation cocktail (clear reagent) from monocyte isolation kit (5 sec).

components.data: Add 200 μl RapidSpheres and 200 μl isolation cocktail to each 14 ml tube.  Pulse vortex tubes 5-10 times to mix.  Incubate 5 min at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 200 μl RapidSpheres and 200 μl isolation cocktail to each 14 ml tube.  Pulse vortex tubes 5-10 times to mix.  Incubate 5 min at room temperature.

components.data: Add 8 ml isolation buffer to each tube and invert 5 times to mix (make sure to hold tube cap down tightly to avoid spilling sample).  Move tubes to magnet and incubate 5 min at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 8 ml isolation buffer to each tube and invert 5 times to mix (make sure to hold tube cap down tightly to avoid spilling sample).  Move tubes to magnet and incubate 5 min at room temperature.

components.data: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to new 14 ml tube.  Supernatants will be a somewhat clarified red color.  Red blood cells will not stick well to the magnet during the first transfer step (this will not affect performance).  For best yield, transfer ~ 0.5 ml of red blood cells from as well.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to new 14 ml tube.  Supernatants will be a somewhat clarified red color.  Red blood cells will not stick well to the magnet during the first transfer step (this will not affect performance).  For best yield, transfer ~ 0.5 ml of red blood cells from as well.

components.data: Add 200 μl RapidSpheres and 200 μl isolation cocktail to each 14 ml tube.  Invert 5 times to mix (make sure to hold tube cap down tightly to avoid spilling sample).  Incubate 5 min at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 200 μl RapidSpheres and 200 μl isolation cocktail to each 14 ml tube.  Invert 5 times to mix (make sure to hold tube cap down tightly to avoid spilling sample).  Incubate 5 min at room temperature.

components.data: Move tubes to magnet and incubate at least 5 minutes at room temperature.  A 10 minute incubation on this step appears to improve red blood cell removal and does not affect cell viability.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Move tubes to magnet and incubate at least 5 minutes at room temperature.  A 10 minute incubation on this step appears to improve red blood cell removal and does not affect cell viability.

components.data: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to new 14 ml tube.  Supernatants will now be a clarified yellow color similar to blood plasma.  Red blood cells should stick well to the magnet during this transfer step.  Do not remove or disturb red blood cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to new 14 ml tube.  Supernatants will now be a clarified yellow color similar to blood plasma.  Red blood cells should stick well to the magnet during this transfer step.  Do not remove or disturb red blood cells.

components.data: Move new tubes directly to the magnet and incubate 5 minutes at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Move new tubes directly to the magnet and incubate 5 minutes at room temperature.

components.data: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to appropriate tubes for centrifugation (note 1).  Supernatants will be a clarified yellow color similar to blood plasma.  Residual red blood cells should form a very thin line on the back of the tube against the magnet.  Do not remove or disturb red blood cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant from tubes by pipetting and transfer to appropriate tubes for centrifugation (note 1).  Supernatants will be a clarified yellow color similar to blood plasma.  Residual red blood cells should form a very thin line on the back of the tube against the magnet.  Do not remove or disturb red blood cells.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 11 of Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.annotation: (1) We use 5 ml tubes (3 per 14 ml tube) for this step as we do not have a good way to centrifuge the 14 ml tubes in our lab.  Choice of tube will depend on availability of rotors for the centrifuge.
source_data.thread_text: (1) We use 5 ml tubes (3 per 14 ml tube) for this step as we do not have a good way to centrifuge the 14 ml tubes in our lab.  Choice of tube will depend on availability of rotors for the centrifuge.
source_data.body: (1) We use 5 ml tubes (3 per 14 ml tube) for this step as we do not have a good way to centrifuge the 14 ml tubes in our lab.  Choice of tube will depend on availability of rotors for the centrifuge.

components.data: Centrifuge cells at 500 × g  for 5 min in refrigerated centrifuge (4-8degC) to pellet cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Centrifuge cells at 500 × g  for 5 min in refrigerated centrifuge (4-8degC) to pellet cells.

components.data: Aspirate supernatants and resuspend in prepared media or buffer for counting (note 2).  A volume of 75-100 μl of media per 1 ml of initial blood that was processed seems to work well and consistently gives a final cell concentration of 4-6 × 10^6 cells / ml.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Aspirate supernatants and resuspend in prepared media or buffer for counting (note 2).  A volume of 75-100 μl of media per 1 ml of initial blood that was processed seems to work well and consistently gives a final cell concentration of 4-6 × 10^6 cells / ml.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.annotation: (2) If red blood cells are visible in the pellet, a red blood cell lysis step can be inserted here.  This is usually not needed and will somewhat decrease total cell yield.
source_data.thread_text: (2) If red blood cells are visible in the pellet, a red blood cell lysis step can be inserted here.  This is usually not needed and will somewhat decrease total cell yield.
source_data.body: (2) If red blood cells are visible in the pellet, a red blood cell lysis step can be inserted here.  This is usually not needed and will somewhat decrease total cell yield.

components.data: Count cells using routine methods (note 3).  Cell viability should be near 100%.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Count cells using routine methods (note 3).  Cell viability should be near 100%.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 14 of Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.annotation: (3) We use a Scepter counter with a 40 μm sensor and dilute the cell suspension 10× in media prior to counting (20 μl cells in 180 μl media).  Note that the Scepter requires serum-free medium as presence of serum in the media will clog the sensor.
source_data.thread_text: (3) We use a Scepter counter with a 40 μm sensor and dilute the cell suspension 10× in media prior to counting (20 μl cells in 180 μl media).  Note that the Scepter requires serum-free medium as presence of serum in the media will clog the sensor.
source_data.body: (3) We use a Scepter counter with a 40 μm sensor and dilute the cell suspension 10× in media prior to counting (20 μl cells in 180 μl media).  Note that the Scepter requires serum-free medium as presence of serum in the media will clog the sensor.

components.data: Proceed to downstream applications.  Cell purity can be checked using flow cytometer with an anti-CD14 antibody (note 4).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Proceed to downstream applications.  Cell purity can be checked using flow cytometer with an anti-CD14 antibody (note 4).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 15 of Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Monocytes from Whole Blood With Magnetic Negative Sorting
source_data.annotation: (4) Note that this particular kit contains anti-CD16 antibodies and thus depletes intermediate (CD14+CD16+) and non-classical monocytes (CD14dimCD16++).  A monocyte kit without CD16 depletion (#19058) is available from Stem Cell Technologies.
source_data.thread_text: (4) Note that this particular kit contains anti-CD16 antibodies and thus depletes intermediate (CD14+CD16+) and non-classical monocytes (CD14dimCD16++).  A monocyte kit without CD16 depletion (#19058) is available from Stem Cell Technologies.
source_data.body: (4) Note that this particular kit contains anti-CD16 antibodies and thus depletes intermediate (CD14+CD16+) and non-classical monocytes (CD14dimCD16++).  A monocyte kit without CD16 depletion (#19058) is available from Stem Cell Technologies.

components.data:
Materials to Prepare:

**Isolation Buffer**: 1 mM EDTA in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS):

-Add 2 ml 0.5 M EDTA to a 1 L bottle of sterile PBS.

-Maintain sterility.

-Store at room temperature.

-Usable at least 6 months.

**Media**

-Various media can be used, depending on downstream assay.

-For counting using a Scepter cell counter (Millipore), serum-free medium is necessary.
components.name: Description

Materials to Prepare:

**Isolation Buffer**: 1 mM EDTA in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS):

-Add 2 ml 0.5 M EDTA to a 1 L bottle of sterile PBS.

-Maintain sterility.

-Store at room temperature.

-Usable at least 6 months.

**Media**

-Various media can be used, depending on downstream assay.

-For counting using a Scepter cell counter (Millipore), serum-free medium is necessary.
